user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_tell:
```c
lfs_soff_t lfs_file_tell(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_tell(%p, %p)", (void*)lfs, (void*)file);
    LFS_ASSERT(lfs_mlist_isopen(lfs->mlist, (struct lfs_mlist*)file));

    lfs_soff_t res = lfs_file_tell_(lfs, file);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_tell -> %"PRId32, res);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_file_tell:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define LFS_ASSERT(test) assert(test)
...
static lfs_soff_t lfs_file_tell_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    (void)lfs;
    return file->pos;
}
...
static bool lfs_mlist_isopen(struct lfs_mlist *head,
        struct lfs_mlist *node) {
    for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &head; *p; p = &(*p)->next) {
        if (*p == (struct lfs_mlist*)node) {
            return true;
        }
    }

    return false;
}
...
typedef int32_t  lfs_soff_t
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef struct lfs_file {
    struct lfs_file *next;
    uint16_t id;
    uint8_t type;
    lfs_mdir_t m;

    struct lfs_ctz {
        lfs_block_t head;
        lfs_size_t size;
    } ctz;

    uint32_t flags;
    lfs_off_t pos;
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_cache_t cache;

    const struct lfs_file_config *cfg;
} lfs_file_t
...
struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    }
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Items examined and reasons they are not MISRA Rule 1.2 issues: 

- LFS_LOCK/LFS_UNLOCK macros: use standard comma operator and cast-to-void — ordinary C, not a compiler extension. 
- LFS_TRACE variadic macro: variadic macros are part of standard C (since C99), not an extension. The macro is simply defined empty. 
- LFS_ASSERT(assert(...)): assert is a standard library macro. 
- Use of (void*) casts in LFS_TRACE calls and (void)lfs in lfs_file_tell_(): standard casts and explicit void casts to suppress unused warnings — not extensions. 
- PRId32 in the format string: macro from <inttypes.h> (standard C) — not an extension. 
- for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &head; ...): declaring a loop-local variable in the for-init and pointer operations are standard C (C99 and later). 
- stdint types (int32_t, uint16_t, etc.), bool, and size types: standard headers/types, not compiler extensions. 
- Struct and typedef declarations (including nested struct tag usage): standard C constructs. 

No compiler-specific keywords, attributes (e.g., __attribute__), asm statements, typeof, statement-expressions, zero-length arrays, flexible array members beyond standard, platform intrinsics, or other documented compiler extensions were present in the supplied fragments. Therefore there are no code fragments to report for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
